Keywords: FLD, Improved practice, Variety, Wheat, Yield INTRODUCTION increase in its production and acreage should be given top priority in order to achieve food and nutritional security Wheat is the important winter season food crop of in the state.

However, success of any crop production India and improvement in its productivity has played a depends on use of appropriate genotype/variety of high key role in making the country self-sufficient in food grain. yield potential and improved nutrient and weed control West Bengal is not a traditional wheat growing state in measures. India.

However, at present, wheat has become a staple food crop next to rice and its consumption is gradually Among the agronomic practices suitable cultivars increasing because of change in food habit and economic plays a significant role in maximizing the crop yield and prosperity. In spite of a wide range of adoptability, little productivity.

Weed control measures is very important attention has been paid towards wheat production and for proper distribution of plants over cultivated area and maximization of yield potential of this crop in West Bengal for better utilization of available soil and natural resources.

and its share to national production is less than one per Most of the farmers in the new alluvial zone of West cent. Productivity of 2.8 t/ha is also far below the national Bengal, avoid growing wheat due to improper knowledge average of 3.14 t/ha (Mukherjee, 2017).

Since wheat is of suitable cultivar and poor nutrient and weeding control a major cereal crop and population is gradually increasing, measures. Hence, an effort made through AICRP on Directorate of Research, Bidhan Chandra Krishi Viswavidyalaya, Kalyani-741235, West Bengal.
STRATEGY OF IMPROVING WHEAT PRODUCTIVITY UNDER NEW ALLUVIAL ZONE 67 Wheat and Barley Improvement, by introducing the established by AICRP on Wheat and Barley Improvement.

recommended technologies of wheat production with Improved variety seed (HD 2967), with seed rate of 100 suitable cultivar through front line demonstration on kg/ha along with recommended dose of fertilizer 150:60:40 farmers field during rabi season of 2014-17. kg of NPK/ha and weed control measures were used.

Crop was sown between18th to 21st November in the METHODOLOGY demonstration field, with 20 cm row spacing. The crop received full dose of P O and K O and half dose of Present study was conducted under the aegis of 2 5 2 nitrogen as basal dose and remaining nitrogen in 2 equal Bidhan Chandra Kristi Viswavidyalaya during winter splits i.e.

at tillering and at boot stage. The source of season of 2014-15, 2015-16 and 2016-17 in the Nadia fertilizer was urea, single super phosphate and muriate district of West Bengal. Participatory rural appraisal of potash for N, P and K, respectively.
Weed control (PRA), group discussion and transect walk were followed measures mainly include, post emergence application of to explore the detail information of study area.

For easy understanding of the farming community of the region, 2, 4 DEE @750 ml/ha was given at 23 DAS (days after training, field day and farmer awareness programme were sowing) followed by one hand weeding at 40 DAS for conducted to excel the farmers understanding and skill complete check of weed during critical period of crop- about the demonstrated technology on wheat.

Field weed competition. Fields were irrigated at the critical demonstrations were conducted under close supervision stages of crop and the crop was harvested between 29th of staff and scientist working under AICRP on Wheat March to 9th April during all the years of demonstration. and Barley.

Total 17 front line demonstrations under real Farmer’s practice constituted seed of age old variety of farming situations were conducted during rabi season of Sonalika. Crop was sown on the same time as 2014-15, 2015-16 and 2016-17 at four different villages demonstration, broadcasting method of sowing, higher namely;.
68 farmers and extension functionaries were organized at demonstration plots to disseminate the technology at large scale. Yield data was collected from farmers practice and demonstration plots.

The grass returns, cost of cultivation, net returns and benefit cost ratio (B:C ratio) were calculated by using prevailing prices of inputs and outputs and finally the extension gap, technology gap and technology index were worked out. Technology gap, extension gap and technology index were measured as per procedure given by Samui et al. (2000).

RESULT AND DISCUSSION The weather data during the crop season are given in Table 1. There was scanty rainfall during the period of study. The minimum and maximum temperature ranged from 11.40 to 15.31 and 29.36 to 35.80, respectively during the years of demonstration.
The relative humidity ranged from 44.56 to 53.26 for minimum and 82.05 to 92.46 per cent for maximum. The sunshine hrs/day varies from 5.16 to 7.54 during the FLD period.

The yields attributing parameters like ear head (no./ m2) and number of tillers/m2 obtained over the years under recommended practice as well as farmers practice are presented in Table 2. Observation revealed that, ear head numbers were registered high with FLD plots compare to farmer’s practice.
Ear head (no./m2) ranged from 236.63-311.23 with mean of 268.92 with improved practices on farmer’s field as against a ranged from 156.33-201.29 with mean of 181.91 in farmer’s practice.

The number of tillers/ m2 of wheat ranged from 305.66 to 341.33 with mean of 322.77 under improved technology as against a ranged from 234.33-256.66 with a mean value of 252.16 recorded under farmers practice. This corroborate with the finding of Mukherjee (2016).
The grain yields of wheat obtained over the years under recommended practice as well as farmers practice are presented in Table 2.

Grain yield is a function of various yield attributing factor and grain yield ranged from 32.95 to 38.43 q/ha with mean grain yield of 36.13 q/ha under improved practice on farmers field as against a grain yield ranged from 21.98 to 24.65 q/ha with a mean of 23.36 q/ha recorded under farmers practice.

The higher grain yield of wide extension gap (Table 2). The technology gap is the wheat under improved practices was due to the use of difference or gap between the demonstration yield and latest high yielding variety, enhance rate of fertilizer potential yield and it was varies during the year of application with proper weed control measures.

Further observation. The trend of technology gap ranging between analysis of Table 2 revealed that, biological yield also 6.57-12.05 q/ha reflected the farmer’s cooperation in varies to the tune of 71.95 to 87.32 q/ha compared to carrying out such demonstration with encouraging results farmer practice with range of 50.32 to 56.39 q/ha.

during the period of study. This gap existed due to Improved technology in the farmer’s field, increase variation in the soil fertility and climatic or weather biological yield to the tune of 27.52 to 66.76 per cent conditions (Table 1). Hence location specific over the age old farmers practice.

The more grain yield recommendations are necessary to bridge the gap. These and biomass production recorded with improved practices findings are similar to the findings of Patel et al. (2013) owing to better utilization of available resources, mainly and Mukherjee (2016a).

The technology index showed because of more dry matter accumulation and yield the feasibility of the evolved technology at the farmer’s attributing characters. field. The lower the value of technology index, the more is the feasibility of the technology.

As such, the reduction Similarly, higher harvest index was recorded under in technology index from 26.67, 14.60 and 17.75 per cent, improved technology (41.36 to 51.46% mean value of respectively during 2014-15, 2015-16 and 2016-17 45.61%) as compared to farmers practice (ranged exhibited the feasibility of the demonstrated technology between 41.97 to 46.60%, mean of 44.90).
The higher in this region. The results of the present study are in values of yield attributing character, yield and harvest recurrence with the findings of Bar and Das (2015).
